transcriptText:
In this lesson, we combine basic elements from lessons 2 & 3 to create 2 simple choreographed routines you can repeat ad lib, until you are ready to unleash your own creativity and flow with the clubs.

What can Indian clubs do for you?

Gently mobilizes the shoulders, elbows and wrists and improve range of motion

Strengthens the shoulder girdle and grip ( muscles and connective tissues) in its full range of motion

Consists of compound movements in multiple planes

Provides low impact cardiovascular exercise

Assists recovery from intense training

Improves the 3 pillars of physical literacy (body control , locomotion and object control)

It is fun and you forget you are training.

The rhythmic and repetitive patterns are highly meditative and calm the nervous system, like meditation.

Cross crawl exercises and other challenging moves improve learning capacity and stimulate neurogenesis, the creation of new brain cells.

❂ Heroic Sport | An ancient discipline

Our clubs are easily adjustable, which is a modern twist on the ancient traditional Indian clubs used to train Tamil and Persian warriors and wrestlers.

Indian clubs were used in Europe and USA for remedial gymnastics in the 18th and 19th century, by pioneers of physiotherapy.

foreign the first short flow I want to share with you is our big enough fluid that we do at every introduction Workshop so anybody can follow along right all the movements start from the left side I'm going to do a version where I'm talking through each of the steps and then one where it's flowing a bit more so order position feet under the hips left side first we're going to do an inner back Circle so that's one two is the right boom three is the front Circle four is the right now both clubs are going to fall to the left then to the right so we've done a figure eight then by the side of the legs I'm going to step forward catch the clubs into my swipe lunge from here I'm going to extend the arms forward okay come back step back into the back swing switch the legs look up extend the arms straight ahead backswing swipe and here we're going out wide we close and we're back to the start so we've got one two three and four five six seven eight nine ten eleven twelve thirteen fourteen fifteen sixteen seventeen 18. now it's possible for you to add again extra wrist circles along the way when you feel comfortable and build up from that routine with the new swings that we you will learn on your Indian club Journey right and last time slide differently slightly different angle for you so we got one two three four five six seven eight nine ten eleven twelve thirteen fourteen fifteen sixteen seventeen eighteen boom you completed your first flow well done [Music] second floor where we're going to introduce a lot more of static holes combined with the swings so from a start position we're going to do a flag press come back to order press out to the side as I step with my left leg bring the clubs overhead and look at them back down to the side flag and I'm going to swing back into my start position yeah flag press front press step with the right look overhead swing back into order press from here I'm going to let both clubs swing out to the side as I step back so swinging to the left stepping back with the right pull the bar open boom stand up flag front press boom swing to the left step with the left whoo boom front press from here I'm going to swing low and do a return like a little dead stop side to side so I'm going to step right one two three moving in opposition and coming back to the center from here across my clubs catch into an overhead squat cross step catch make sure that the knees and the feet are pointing same direction only go to the depth that feels good for you for on press boom same stepping out to the side dead stop one two three Shifting the weight come back to the center press cross and we do a step to the left into our squat boom and you can repeat the flow now so left overhead so we introduced this static holes as a way to build the shoulder endurance and strength boom to the left boom so we're crossing the bow over the front leg pull it open step back in place front press now to the right boom allele pendulum to the right one two three boom press cross step into the overhead squat up press pendulum to the left one two three step back to Center cross overhead squat and we close boom

# [Indian clubs 101 Lesson 4/5:  Simple flows | Free YouTube course for beginners](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZjzXMIs3JZI)

**Visibility**: Public
**Uploaded by**: [Heroic Sport - Indian clubs workouts](http://www.youtube.com/@HeroicSport)
**Uploaded at**: 2023-03-14T05:23:18-07:00
**Published at**: 2023-03-14T05:23:18-07:00
**Length**: 06:09
**Views**: 1890
**Likes**: 44
**Category**: Sports

## Description

```
In this lesson, we combine basic elements from lessons 2 & 3 to create 2 simple choreographed routines you can repeat ad lib, until you are ready to unleash your own creativity and flow with the clubs.

0:05 routine #1
2:41 routine #2 

---
What can Indian clubs do for you?
Watch this: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ft-FL_6s_No

❂ Physical benefits
Gently mobilizes the shoulders, elbows and wrists and improve range of motion
Strengthens the shoulder girdle and grip ( muscles and connective tissues) in its full range of motion
Consists of compound movements in multiple planes
Provides low impact cardiovascular exercise
Assists recovery from intense training
Improves the 3 pillars of physical literacy (body control , locomotion and object control)

❂ Mental benefits
It is fun and you forget you are training.
The rhythmic and repetitive patterns are highly meditative and calm the nervous system, like meditation.
Cross crawl exercises and other challenging moves improve learning capacity and stimulate neurogenesis, the creation of new brain cells.

❂ Heroic Sport | An ancient discipline 
We have created the Pahlavandle ™ range to make it affordable for everyone to discover the benefits of swinging clubs.
Our clubs are easily adjustable, which is a modern twist on the ancient traditional Indian clubs used to train Tamil and Persian warriors and wrestlers. 
Indian clubs were used in Europe and USA for remedial gymnastics in the 18th and 19th century, by pioneers of physiotherapy.
```
